DataElement.preferredName: Renal Cell Carcinoma Histologic Classification Code
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A numeric coded response for the histologic classification of renal cell carcinoma.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Renal Cell Carcinoma Histologic Primary Classification
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information relating to the histologic primary classification of renal cell carcinoma.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Cancer that develops in the lining of the renal tubules, which filter the blood and produce urine.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from the renal parenchyma.  There is a strong correlation between cigarette smoking and the development of renal cell carcinoma.  The clinical presentation includes : hematuria, flank pain and a palpable lumbar mass.  A high percentage of renal cell carcinomas are diagnosed when an ultrasound is performed for other purposes.  Radical nephrectomy is the standard intervention procedure.  Renal cell carcinoma is generally considered to be resistant to radiation treatment and chemotherapy.

Property.preferredDefinition: Of or relating to histology.:Occurring first in time or sequence; original. (American Heritage Dictionary):Classification; the grouping of things into classes or categories.

Concepts.definition: Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues.
Occurring first in time or sequence; original; of greatest rank or importance or value.
A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Mixed Histology Less Than Twenty Five Percent Unit Clear Cell Renal Cell Carcinoma

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Mixed Histology Less Than Twenty Five Percent Unit Clear Cell Renal Cell Carcinoma
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Involving or composed of different kinds.: The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.: A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that an object of interest is smaller than another object in quantity or measure or value or status.: A natural number greater than twenty-four and less than twenty-six and the quantity that it denotes.: A unit for expressing a number as a fraction of hundred (on the basis of a rate or proportion per hundred).: A malignant epithelial neoplasm of the kidney characterized by the presence of lipid-containing clear cells within a vascular network.  The tumor may metastasize to unusual sites and late metastasis is common.

Concepts.definition: Involving or composed of different kinds.

The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.
A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that an object of interest is smaller than another object in quantity or measure or value or status.
A natural number greater than twenty-four and less than twenty-six and the quantity that it denotes.
A unit for expressing a number as a fraction of hundred (on the basis of a rate or proportion per hundred).

A malignant epithelial neoplasm of the kidney characterized by the presence of lipid-containing clear cells within a vascular network.  The tumor may metastasize to unusual sites and late metastasis is common.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Mixed Histology Greater Than or Equal To Twenty Five Percent Unit Clear Cell Renal Cell Carcinoma

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Mixed Histology Greater Than or Equal To Twenty Five Percent Unit Clear Cell Renal Cell Carcinoma
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Involving or composed of different kinds.: The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.: A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that either both objects are the same in quantity or measure or value or status or that the object of interest exceeds the other object in one of these ways.: A natural number greater than twenty-four and less than twenty-six and the quantity that it denotes.: A unit for expressing a number as a fraction of hundred (on the basis of a rate or proportion per hundred).: A malignant epithelial neoplasm of the kidney characterized by the presence of lipid-containing clear cells within a vascular network.  The tumor may metastasize to unusual sites and late metastasis is common.

Concepts.definition: Involving or composed of different kinds.

The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that either both objects are the same in quantity or measure or value or status or that the object of interest exceeds the other object in one of these ways.
A natural number greater than twenty-four and less than twenty-six and the quantity that it denotes.
A unit for expressing a number as a fraction of hundred (on the basis of a rate or proportion per hundred).

A malignant epithelial neoplasm of the kidney characterized by the presence of lipid-containing clear cells within a vascular network.  The tumor may metastasize to unusual sites and late metastasis is common.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of carcinoma that comprises a minority of renal cell carcinomas.  It is characterized by loss of chromosomes 1 and Y.  Based on the cytoplasmic characteristics of the neoplastic cells, this type of carcinoma is classified as classic (typical) or eosinophilic.  It has a much better prognosis than other renal cell carcinomas.

Concepts.definition: A type of carcinoma that comprises a minority of renal cell carcinomas.  It is characterized by loss of chromosomes 1 and Y.  Based on the cytoplasmic characteristics of the neoplastic cells, this type of carcinoma is classified as classic (typical), eosinophilic, or oncocytic.  It has a much better prognosis than other renal cell carcinomas.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A malignant epithelial neoplasm characterized by a papillary growth pattern. A papillary carcinoma may be composed of glandular cells (papillary adenocarcinoma), squamous cells (papillary squamous cell carcinoma), or transitional cells (papillary transitional cell carcinoma). Bladder carcinoma is a representative example of papillary transitional cell carcinoma.

Concepts.definition: A malignant epithelial neoplasm characterized by a papillary growth pattern. A papillary carcinoma may be composed of glandular cells (papillary adenocarcinoma), squamous cells (papillary squamous cell carcinoma), or transitional cells (papillary transitional cell carcinoma). Bladder carcinoma is a representative example of papillary transitional cell carcinoma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A malignant epithelial neoplasm of the kidney characterized by the presence of lipid-containing clear cells within a vascular network.  The tumor may metastasize to unusual sites and late metastasis is common.

Concepts.definition: A malignant epithelial neoplasm of the kidney characterized by the presence of lipid-containing clear cells within a vascular network.  The tumor may metastasize to unusual sites and late metastasis is common.
